info.game_comments:
David Madden game 14.
Last game of Season 21.

(1, 1).clue: In 1938 Otto Hahn & Fritz Strassman discovered nuclear fission by splitting atoms of this element

(2, 1).clue: This song could be John Henry's reply to the question "Where ya been?"

(3, 1).clue: Are you ready to rumba?  Head for the rumba room at this California theme park's Citywalk

(4, 1).clue: This hero of WWII was the "Lion of Luzon", but on Bataan he was known as "Dugout Doug"

(5, 1).clue: In 1999 this General Mills cereal came out with Millenios, featuring 2s as well as the usual Os

(1, 2).clue: Sublimation is the process by which a solid changes into a gas without going through this stage

(2, 2).clue: This song is popular during a certain NFL team's introductions

(3, 2).clue: Tongues are wagging that Tongue & Groove on Peachtree Rd. is one of this city's top nightspots

(4, 2).clue: For his leadership that resulted in final victory, General Ulysses S. Grant was known as "The Hero of" this location

(5, 2).clue: In the '70s they called a "blended flavored (cherry & other flavorings) carbonated beverage" Mr. this

(1, 3).clue: Term first used by James Watt for a unit equivalent to 550 foot-pounds of work per second

(2, 3).clue: Numerical phrase for the time when you normally hear the following

(3, 3).clue: For years you could find Pete Fountain playing the clarinet at his own club on Poydras St. in this Southern city

(4, 3).clue: The parents of this mythological hero were told he'd live to a ripe old age as long as he never looked at himself

(5, 3).clue: Calistoga mineral water is from this California valley that's famous for its vineyards

(1, 4).clue: This branch of physics deals with heat & includes cryogenics, which deals with extremely low temperatures

(2, 4).clue: Jimmy Cagney could tell you the name of this up-tempo foot stomper

(3, 4).clue: Perhaps because of its wall of fire, Rumjungle in this "Bay" hotel has been called "the hottest club in Vegas"

(4, 4).clue: This title swashbuckling hero rescues aristocrats during the French Revolution in an Orczy work

(5, 4).clue: This marshmallow brand is named for the manufacturing process that infuses air into the marshmallows

(1, 5).clue: Theodore Maiman used this gem in producing the world's first laser in 1960

(2, 5).clue: Sir Edmund Hillary might enjoy this spiritually inspired favorite

(3, 5).clue: "Praise the Lord and pass the biscuits" at a Sunday gospel brunch at one of these clubs nicknamed HOB

(4, 5).clue: A 15th century poem by a guy known as Blind Harry is the main source for the life of this Scottish hero

(5, 5).clue: Mr. T was featured in Busta Rhymes' 2002 video "Pass" this Napoleonic cognac

(1, 1).clue: The first Dairy Queen opened in Illinois, & the first McDonald's opened in this state

(2, 1).clue: "Dark Lover" by Emily Leider is the first fully documented biography of this early Hollywood heartthrob

(3, 1).clue: In Hinduism, a shortcut to paradise is to die in this 1,560-mile river

(4, 1).clue: Tenor Heinrich Vogl created the roles of Loge in "Das Rheingold" & Siegmund in "Die Walkure" by this composer

(5, 1).clue: In Chapter 1 of this book, Mole says, "Onion-sauce! Onion-sauce!" to a group of rabbits who have no satisfactory reply

(6, 1).clue: Try to remember this musical that features the song "Try To Remember"

(1, 2).clue: (Cheryl of the Clue Crew reports from Chicago's Adler Planetarium.)  In celebration of his 500th birthday, a statue of this Polish astronomer was dedicated outside the Adler Planetarium in 1973

(2, 2).clue: In a 2003 bestseller, A. Scott Berg "Remembered" this legendary actress who passed away at age 96

(3, 2).clue: In chapter 3 of the Biblical book named for him, Joshua leads the Israelites across this river

(4, 2).clue: In 1902 Clifford Berryman drew a famous editorial cartoon of this man refusing to shoot a bear cub

(5, 2).clue: The power-mad Gen. Woundwort makes life miserable for the other bunnies in this 1972 novel by Richard Adams

(6, 2).clue: Gosh darn it, it's cursing & swearing

(1, 3).clue: These caramel candies debuted in 1935, long before Ann Miller's Broadway musical of the same name

(2, 3).clue: (Hi, I'm Bob Woodward.) In my book "Wired", I wrote about "the short life & fast times" of this comedian

(3, 3).clue: It's estimated that more than 20% of the world's unfrozen fresh water is in this Siberian lake

(4, 3).clue: War correspondent Martha Gellhorn was married to this author from 1940 to 1945

(5, 3).clue: Mammy-Bammy Big-Money is the witch rabbit who lives in a swamp in this man's Uncle Remus stories

(6, 3).clue: This American grape that makes a fine wine has been traced back to an Italian variety known as primitivo

(1, 4).clue: Art Linkletter was on the $100,000 bill in the 1960 edition of Milton Bradley's Game of this

(2, 4).clue: "Natasha" tells of her tumultuous life, her many loves and her mysterious death in 1981

(3, 4).clue: The Tipitapa River connects Lake Nicaragua with this other large lake to the north

(4, 4).clue: Self-destructive poet Delmore Schwartz inspired this author's novel "Humboldt's Gift"

(5, 4).clue: In Beatrix Potter's "Tale of the Flopsy Bunnies", Flopsy marries this bunny

(1, 5).clue: What a turn-on! "Energy Turns On the World" was the theme of the 1982 World's Fair in this Tennessee city

(2, 5).clue: "Mercy, Mercy Me", a biography of this singer, was published in 2004 to coincide with the 20th anniv. of his death

(3, 5).clue: Perhaps Enya could tell you that part of this 1,600-mile-long river flows along the Venezuela-Colombia border

(4, 5).clue: In 1929 Hugo Eckener commanded this famous airship wath a 2-word name on a flight around the world

(5, 5).clue: Howard R. Garis wrote a book about this avuncular rabbit "and the Runaway Cheese"

(0, 0).clue: This actor who turned down the role of Dirty Harry played 142 leading roles, a Guinness record
